review.title: On the Min-cost Traveling Salesman Problem with Drone
review.abstract: Once known to be used exclusively in military domain, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) have stepped up to become a part of new logistic method in commercial sector called "last-mile delivery". In this novel approach, small UAVs, also known as drones, are deployed in tandem with the trucks to deliver goods to customers. Under research context, it gives rise to a new variant of the traveling salesman problem (TSP), of which we call TSP with drone (TSP-D). In this paper, we propose two heuristics: route first - cluster second, and cluster first - route second, to solve the problem efficiently. A new mixed integer programming formulation is also introduced to handle the cluster step in both heuristics. We conduct an experiment, adapting different profit functions of the MIP model, in both heuristics, to many instances with different sizes and characteristics. The numerical analysis shows not only a significant savings compare to truck-only delivery but also a superior performance against the previous work.

sections.heading: II.2 Time span
sections.text: We define a time span - the maximum time allowed for either the truck or the drone to return to the meeting point sooner or later than each other - which means that a vehicle can wait for the other to arrive at a certain time so that the truck can make its timetable flexible (see Figure 8). For example, if the drone first arrives at a customer location, it can wait for the truck, and when the truck arrives at the location, it can proceed immediately to the next location without waiting for the drone. The value of the time span affects the quality of the solution. If the time span is too short, there is less flexibility for the truck timetable with the drone. On the other hand, the high time span makes the truck wait at some point or is waited a long time by the drone, resulting in a longer total driving time.
